comments.html: Let's not forget that most of this cheap Linksys hardware runs Linux inside. What people want is convenience and a pre-packaged product. Open-source crowd alone is rarely good at delivering that unless the product is really mass market.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
Careful Ivan

Next thing you will be telling us is the emperor has no clothes!!
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html:
I've also been told you can put Linux on a 2500 as well!!

http://www.kdvelectronics.eu/uClinux-cisco2500/uClinux-cisco2500.html
comments.name: Unknown

comments.html: You have to be careful not to expand the debate over an integrated server to full-blown open source network infrastructure. While the AXP seems like a neat idea to me, it also seems overpriced and underpowered, and Cisco will probably cripple available functionality.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
@vladimir: thanks for the information. Never touched a Linksys box in my life :) And I completely agree with you.

@whisper: I've seen that a few years ago, but could never figure out why I'd do it (if nothing else, a 2500 is way louder than an old low-end PC :).

@stretch: Absolutely agree .. and that was exactly my point - the writers I've quoted should tell us something useful about AXP.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
@stretch: ... and, yes, it looks like the functionality is severely limited, but mainly for security reasons that I can fully agree with.

Maybe, just maybe, if I could get my hands on a sample ...
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: I am a huge open source kind of person, but one thing I like not having to worry about is a hard drive failure in my router :). We lose PC hardware everyday here.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
@Carl Yost Jr
use Compact Flash card instead of spinning hard drive :)
